close_symbols: definition of `true` (e.g. inclusion/definition from <stdbool.h> or equivalent)
explanation:
To determine whether the target function uses any compiler language extensions (per the MISRA rule), the analyzer must inspect not just this function body but the declarations/definitions of the types, macros, constants and callees it uses. For each symbol above:

- OS_object_token_t (type/definition): the function dereferences token->lock_mode and passes token to other functions; the type definition may contain anonymous unions/structs, bit-fields, or other nonstandard constructs (language extensions) that would violate the rule.

- OS_common_record_t (type/definition): the function accesses obj->active_id and obj->refcount; the struct definition must be checked for anonymous members, packed attributes, bit-fields, flexible array members, or compiler-specific extensions.

- osal_id_t (typedef/definition): this integer type alias might use compiler-specific integer attributes, extended integer types, or unusual typedef constructs that are extensions.

- OS_LOCK_MODE_RESERVED, OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE, OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE, OS_LOCK_MODE_REFCOUNT: these lock-mode constants (or enum values) could be defined using compiler-specific extensions (e.g. bit-field macros, extension attributes). Also their underlying type (if an enum) may be compiler-dependent.

- OS_OBJECT_ID_RESERVED: constant value may use nonstandard suffixes or macros; its definition may be a macro that uses extensions (e.g. statement expressions).

- OS_ERROR, OS_SUCCESS, OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE, OS_ERR_INVALID_ID, OS_ERR_OBJECT_IN_USE: error-code constants/macros need inspection to ensure they are not defined using language extensions (macros with GCC extensions, attributes, etc.).

- OS_ObjectIdGlobalFromToken, OS_ObjectIdFromToken, OS_ObjectIdIsValid, OS_ObjectIdEqual, OS_WaitForStateChange, OS_Unlock_Global (declarations/definitions): these callees might be macros, inline functions, or functions decorated with compiler-specific attributes (e.g. __attribute__, calling-convention extensions), or implemented using statement-expressions/asm. Their declarations/definitions must be checked for any use of language extensions. In particular, OS_ObjectIdEqual and OS_ObjectIdIsValid are commonly implemented as macros — macro bodies must be examined for GCC statement expressions or other extensions.

- definition of `true` (e.g. <stdbool.h> or equivalent): the function uses while (true); the definition of true/boolean type should be standard; if the project defines its own boolean macros using extensions, that would be relevant.

Collecting these symbols (their headers/definitions) lets the next agent inspect whether any nonstandard language extensions (compiler-specific attributes, statement expressions, anonymous/unnamed struct/union usage, asm, unusual storage-class specifiers, extended integer types, etc.) appear in the types/macros/decls referenced by the target function.
